dashboard.label: README
dashboard.description: This guides you on how to use this AbuseIPDB app for interacting with the API.

div.p: This app was developed by Damien Molina. I was trying to use AbuseIPDB public API with Splunk Enterprise, but none of the available applications were doing what I wanted to do, even the official one. So, here it is!
First thing, here is an exhaustive list of the possible commands this app is supporting.
You can tell the abuseipdb command what to do using the mode option like | abuseipdb mode=report.
Note: default mode is check
div.h2: # Check - Check an IP abuse score
div.p: This command retrieves the abuse confidence score of a given IP address. If the command passes, new fields will be added to every events.

ul.li: mode=check: The command mode for checking an IP.
ip: An explicit IP address, or a Splunk field name containing the IP.
age: (optional) Time range to check the IP on. Integer between 1 and 365, default is 30.
publiconly: (optional) A boolean to only check public IP addresses for saving some API calls. Default is False.

div.p: In the middle of a search:
Copy-paste example: (ip option as a field-name)

pre.code: | makeresults | eval ip_in_event = "64.62.197.152" | abuseipdb mode=check ip=ip_in_event

div.p: That could also have been replaced with: (ip option as a string)
Note: You can either pass an IP address (like 127.0.0.1) or a network range (like 192.168.0.0/24) to this command. With a range:

pre.code: | makeresults | eval range = "64.62.197.152/30" | abuseipdb mode=check ip=range age=10

div.h2: # Report - Report an IP for abusive behavior
div.p: This command reports the given IP address for abusive behavior.

ul.li: mode=report: The command mode for reporting an IP.
ip: An explicit IP address, or a Splunk field name containing the IP.
categories: The abusive categories the IP is matching (separated by comma), as described in AbuseIPDB documentation.
comment: A descriptive text of the attack i.e. server logs, port numbers, etc.

div.h4: In the middle of a search

pre.code: ... | abuseipdb mode=report ip=ip category="1,3" comment="XSS attempts" | ...

div.p: Copy-paste example:

pre.code: | makeresults | eval ip_in_event = "127.0.0.2" | abuseipdb mode=report ip=ip_in_event categories=2 comment="For a test"

div.p: But all parameters can be passed from the event:

pre.code: | makeresults | eval ip_in_event = "127.0.0.2", categories = "1,3", comment = "For testing purpose" | abuseipdb mode=report ip=ip_in_event categories=categories comment=comment

div.p: Note:: be sure to not send any personally identifiable message in the comment field.
div.h2: # Reports - See reports of a given IP
div.p: This command gathers all reports sent regarding a given IP address.

ul.li: mode=reports: The command mode for getting the reports an IP
ip: An explicit IP address, or a Splunk field name containing the IP
age: (optional) Time range to check the IP on. Integer between 1 and 365, default is 30.

div.p: This search must be used on the top-level search.
Example with the categories:

pre.code: | abuseipdb mode=reports ip="64.62.197.152" age=10 | table * | makemv delim="," abuseipdb_categories | lookup AbuseIPDB_Categories id as abuseipdb_categories

div.h2: # Blacklist - Get all IP with a confidence score
div.p: This command gets all the IP addresses with a specific confidence score and upper.

ul.li: mode=blacklist: The command mode for getting a list of the most abusive IP addresses.
confidence: The minimum confidence score to request (integer between 1 and 100).
limit: (optional) The maximum number of requests to request to the API. Default: 100.
ipVersion: (optional) What IP versions should only be requested. Possible values: 4, 6 or mixed (both 4 and 6). Default: mixed.
onlyCountries: (optional) Specific countries to request only, separated by comma.
exceptCountries: (optional) Remove some countries from the API request, separated by comma.

div.p: Note: the number of returned results mainly depends on your subscription. See AbuseIPDB website to have more details.
